Bachelor of Science in Accountancy

Program at a Glance

Accounting is the language of business; all businesspeople use it to communicate. Even if you do not aspire to a career in accounting, it is an important place to begin your career in business. A sound working knowledge of accounting is necessary if you want to rise through the ranks of the business world.

Careers

You’ll be well prepared for employment in the public, corporate, not-for-profit, and government accounting sectors. Accounting majors typically participate in well-paid internships that often lead to entry-level jobs with Big 4 accounting firms, Fortune 500 companies, and top-tier financial institutions. Internships are valuable for building real-world experience and a professional network.

A wide range of career opportunities are available to our graduates, including public accounting, government, and private industry. All Big Four public accounting firms, many medium- and small-sized accounting firms, and a large number of private companies visit campus to recruit our students. Some of the most exciting opportunities are in forensic accounting — the study of fraudulent financial activity. Career opportunities also exist with the FBI, GAO, and the IRS.

70% of majors
complete an internship

90% of interns
receive job offers from their employers

Top Employers
Bank of America, Crowe Horwarth LLP, Deloitte, Ernst & Young, JP Morgan Chase & Co., KPMG, Merrill Lynch, PricewaterhouseCoopers, Wilkin & Guttenplan, WithumSmith and Brown

Ranked No. 23 on Accounting.com’s list of the nation’s best such programs, the Accounting program at TCNJ has a longstanding reputation for preparing exceptional accountants. 

Accounting graduates have enjoyed remarkable success, as evidenced by high CPA exam pass rates, a 60- to 70-percent recruitment rate by public accounting firms, and a 90- to 95-percent job-offer rate from employers to their TCNJ accounting interns. 

The program also provides excellent preparation for graduate studies, as exemplified by the fact that our graduates have earned law degrees from Harvard Law School and PhDs from institutions such as Rutgers and Temple University.

Programs of Study

Bachelor’s degree
Accountancy, BS

Accelerated degrees
Accounting and Business Analytics, BS/MSAccountancy and Business Administration, BS/MBAAccountancy and Public Health, BS/MPH

CPA licensure
Pathway to CPA Licensure

The Bachelor of Science in Accountancy (BS) program consists of 10 accounting courses that integrate the study of theory and the current practice of accounting with research and computer applications. Students are in small classes of no more than 30 students, have opportunities to collaborate with faculty on research projects, and are encouraged to study abroad.

The 150-hour requirement for the Certified Public Accountant (CPA) Licensure program provides a pathway for those graduates interested in sitting for the CPA exam. To obtain the necessary credits for CPA licensure at the undergraduate level, students may pursue a second major or minor or take extra electives to round out their program.

Students are in small classes of no more than 30 students, have opportunities to collaborate with faculty on research projects, and are encouraged to study abroad.

Accounting Minor

Two tracks: financial accounting and managerial accounting

Information Systems and Technology Minor

Students learn how to utilize technology in businesses and other organizations. Students also learn about information systems, systems design, databases, project management, web design, and business analytics. In addition, they will acquire the broad managerial and organizational knowledge necessary to work in today’s technology-driven global economy.

Experiential Learning

Students can expect small, engaging classes in a collaborative setting—including a hands-on audit lab—and close faculty mentorship. Our graduates enjoy remarkable success, with high pass rates on the CPA exam and a 60 to 70 percent recruitment rate with public accounting firms. Accounting students move through the program as a cohort, sharing the same classes and the same professors throughout a structured, four-year curriculum. This student community is remarkably close-knit and supportive of one another. They further strengthen this bond through active student organizations.

Internships

The department encourages students to pursue internships to gain valuable real-world experience and build a professional network. TCNJ’s proximity to Philadelphia and New York City offers the opportunity to work in two of the largest business centers in the country. We assist students in finding internships at top-tier firms by leveraging our alumni network and the professionals at TCNJ’s Career Center. In addition, an internship coordinator within the department supports students with mentoring and supervising these internships.

Our students have completed internships at companies such as Deloitte, Ernst & Young, Johnson & Johnson, KPMG, and PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Student Organizations

All student organizations sponsor career planning and other co-curricular activities.

  • Beta Alpha Psi – The International Honorary Organization for Financial Information Students and Professionals
  • Institute of Management Accountants (IMA)
  • National Association of Black Accountants (NABA)

Faculty Expertise

TCNJ faculty are active scholars with ongoing research and contributions to auditing, cost, financial accounting, information systems, forensic accounting, and tax.

Full-time faculty who are active researchers and experts in specialized accounting fields offer classes, including auditing, cost, financial accounting, information systems, forensic accounting, and tax. Opportunities are available to collaborate with faculty on research projects, and students are encouraged to study abroad.
